## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 379, 313]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 765, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 875, 711]]<|/det|>
At point P, the gas has volume \(950 \text{cm}^3\), pressure \(2.10 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(280 \text{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 723, 918, 757]]<|/det|>
The gas is heated at constant volume and \(97.0 \text{J}\) of thermal energy is transferred to the gas. Its pressure and temperature change so that the gas is at point Q on Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 770, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
The gas then undergoes the change from point Q to point R and then from point R back to point P, as shown on Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 845, 89]]<|/det|> Some energy changes that take place during the cycle PQRP are shown in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 885, 234]]<|/det|>

thermal energy transferred to gas/J+97.00....................
work done on gas/J....................-42.5+37.0
increase in internal energy of gas/J............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 342, 564, 361]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 920, 408]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 920, 454]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 612, 532, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 608, 662]]<|/det|>
Plate A is earthed and plate B is at a potential of \(-75 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 767, 693]]<|/det|>
A helium nucleus is situated between the plates, a distance \(x\) from plate A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 706, 648, 724]]<|/det|>
Initially, the helium nucleus is at rest on plate A where \(x = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 181, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 737, 920, 785]]<|/det|>
The helium nucleus is free to move between the plates. By considering energy changes of the helium nucleus, explain why the speed at which it reaches plate B is independent of the separation of the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 892, 920, 910]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 116, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the nucleus after it has moved a distance \(x = 0.40 \text{cm}\) from plate A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 338, 920, 356]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 256, 336, 275]]<|/det|>

A solenoid S is wound on a soft-iron core, as shown in Fig. 9.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 541, 561, 560]]<|/det|>
A Hall probe is close to the other end of the core.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 573, 920, 606]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 618, 801, 637]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
A sample of a different radioactive isotope has an initial activity of \(4.6 \times 10^{3} \text{Bq}\). The sample must be stored safely until its activity is reduced to \(1.0 \times 10^{3} \text{Bq}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 907, 586]]<|/det|>
The decay constant of the isotope is \(5.5 \times 10^{-7} \text{s}^{-1}\). The decay products are not radioactive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 598, 769, 616]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 784, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
